text.text: An equitable process is the foundation for equitable outcomes. The ERB centers equity by:
• Guiding users through identifying and engaging disproportionately impacted members of the community
• Reducing barriers to attending workshops and participating in planning activities
• Using a guided process and activities that are facilitated with equity principles including inclusivity, accessibility, accountability, justice, relationship building, and strengthening capacity
• Illuminating who is made most vulnerable to disaster and climate change impacts, why, and how with attention to deeply rooted social and environmental inequalities

• Grounding assessments in local knowledge, incorporating all perspectives from the community and building a stronger sense of community trust, while providing options and guidance for supplemental data collection depending on user interest and capacity

• Using human-centered activities, such as Storytelling, that promote respect, relationship-building, and empower the voices of community members, particularly those who have been historically underrepresented, underserved, and disproportionately impacted
• Developing actions which see benefits equitably distributed across the community
